title: 3 Simple Ways to Unmount a Drive

steps.title: Open the File Explorer.
steps.content: Open the File Explorer . Right-click the Start menu and select File Explorer . On Windows 7 and Vista, click Computer in the right column. Alternatively, press the Win key. If you need to remove or replace a physical hard drive built into your computer, see this article instead.

steps.title: Click This PC.
steps.content: Click This PC . This may also look like Computer or My Computer .

steps.title: Click the drive you want to unmount.
steps.content: Click the drive you want to unmount. A list of all currently active drives will be available under the "Devices and drives" header. This drive must be either a removable drive (e.g., a flash drive or SD card) or a secondary internal drive.

steps.title: Click ⏏ Eject.
steps.content: Click ⏏ Eject . This will be in the Drive Tools tab. If you aren't already on this tab, click it to navigate there now. Once you click Eject , you'll see the drive's icon disappear from the File Explorer window, and a notification letting you know that it's safe to remove the drive will appear.

steps.title: Physically remove the drive from your computer.
steps.content: Physically remove the drive from your computer. This will complete the unmounting process.

steps.title: Unmount and unassign the drive (optional).
steps.content: Unmount and unassign the drive (optional). If you want to change or remove the drive letter, you can use the Disk Management app. This is helpful if you have a lot of partitions or volumes, or if you'd rather manually mount the drive yourself. Do the following: Press the Windows key + R to open the Run menu. Type diskmgmt.msc and press Enter . Right-click the drive. Click Change Drive Letter and Paths . Click Remove . Click Yes . Close Disk Management.

steps.title: Open the Finder.
steps.content: Open the Finder. This can be found in the Dock.

steps.title: Click ⏏ Eject next to the drive.
steps.content: Click ⏏ Eject next to the drive. You can find this in the left panel. This will safely disconnect the drive from your device. [1] X Research source Alternatively, you can drag the drive to the Trash to quickly eject it.

steps.title: Physically remove the drive from your computer.
steps.content: Physically remove the drive from your computer. This will complete the unmounting process.

steps.title: Unmount a disk without ejecting it (optional).
steps.content: Unmount a disk without ejecting it (optional). If you want to unmount an internal disk drive, do the following: Open the Disk Utility app. [2] X Research source Select the disk or disk set you want to unmount. Click Unmount .

steps.title: Open the Terminal.
steps.content: Open the Terminal . On most devices, you can use the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + Alt + T .

steps.title: Type df -h and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Type df -h and press ↵ Enter . This will list all human readable drives on your system. Take note of the drive's path.

steps.title: Type sudo umount followed by the drive's path.
steps.content: Type sudo umount followed by the drive's path. You must have superuser privileges to do this. Note : The command is umount , not unmount .

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter . The drive will be unmounted.

steps.title: Physically remove the drive from your computer.
steps.content: Physically remove the drive from your computer. This will complete the unmounting process.
